content: Edited out unwanted UTF-8 (won't) in "JBM Email" validator case.

Discovered an important rule (modulo) after writing my algo. It would have been nice to have it in the example as it makes 75% of the tests fail.
A bit disappointed with the statement.
Short and sweet. Nice puzzle. I have voted to approve.

In edge cases, there are 7 lines instead of 8.
Ha, there is an empty line at the end. :-\

Got it through the bug (https://forum.codingame.com/t/bug-instability-in-the-draft-community-problem-ide/2135/2?u=jbm), but, really, it felt more like a workaround than a solution, let alone an explanation.
Good catch. It's really intended to be 7, having the empty line in the middle of the expected output is painful enough as is.

Not quite sure what you mean by that.
The modulo is explicitly in the statement; and I don't think you can reliably pass the Edge Cases test without it.
If you think I should have made Edge Cases the example, I beg to differ. The example is supposed to give a taste of the problem, *not* serve as a complete test suite.

Did you attempt to solve the problem by guessing the statement instead of reading it? Surely at some point you must have wondered how to fit an ever-growing choice number with a permanently-constrained clause count?
Got it in Python anyway, even with the empty line.
